title: ASR-FAIRBENCH: Measuring and Benchmarking Equity Across Speech Recognition Systems
author: Anand Rai (Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur), Satyam Rahangdale (Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur), Utkarsh Anand (Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur), Animesh Mukherjee (Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces a fairness benchmark for Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), which is highly relevant to Haohe Liu's research on audio processing and could inform the development of fairer speech technologies in his projects.
field: Social and Economic Aspects of ML-Fairness
background: The ASR-FAIRBENCH leaderboard evaluates speech recognition system performance across different demographic groups to ensure technological fairness.
contribution: ASR-FAIRBENCH introduces the Fairness-Adjusted ASR Score (FAAS) to solve the issue of disparity in ASR accuracy among various demographic groups, achieving a more equitable evaluation framework for ASR systems.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous benchmarks focused solely on overall accuracy, often overlooking fairness across demographic groups.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines traditional metrics with fairness assessments using Poisson regression to provide a multifaceted evaluation.

key_innovation: The integration of fairness metrics with ASR accuracy creates a more nuanced evaluation system that helps identify and address biases in speech recognition models.
real_world_impact: By promoting fairness in ASR technologies, this benchmark could lead to more inclusive applications in voice recognition software, enhancing usability for diverse user groups.

new_terms.Fairness-Adjusted ASR Score (FAAS): **Fairness-Adjusted ASR Score (FAAS)** is a metric that combines traditional ASR accuracy measures with evaluations of fairness across demographic groups to encourage equitable performance in ASR systems.
new_terms.Word Error Rate (WER): **Word Error Rate (WER)** is a common metric used to assess the accuracy of speech recognition systems, calculated based on the number of substitutions, deletions, and insertions during transcription.
